IRS990.Desc: Postsecondary Education: The University taught around 12,935 students and convocated around 2,868 students who obtained their Bachelors degrees, Masters degrees, PhD degrees, as well as certificates and diplomas.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: Maintain Facilities used for Programs: the University owns, runs, and maintains the facilities necessary to provide its teaching and conduct its research (23 Buildings). It also purchases and maintains equipment necessary to carry out its programs, such as computers and lab equipment.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: Science and Technology Research, General/Other: The University carries out Research projects and other Special Projects as part of its mandate. It is a requirement of Faculty members to carry out research and public service (504 Full-time Faculty).

ProgSrvcAccomActyOtherGrp.Desc: Student Services Programs: The University provides services to students, such as residences, bookstore, printing, parking, and food services. (12,935 Students)
Scholarship Programs: The University receives donations specifically to provide scholarships and bursaries to its students to encourage continued learning. (12,935 Students)

ContractorCompensationGrp.ServicesDesc: Construction of College Avenue and College West Building
Construction, Development and Maintenance of Parks

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The MacKenzie Art Gallery manages part of the University's art collection as described in the Note to these Financial Statements. The university also owns various works of Art including paintings, sculptures and drawings. Additions to and disposals of these collections are generally few. During the year, the University accepted donations of art works totaling $507 (2017 - $287), of which $208 is part of the Schumiatcher donation (2017 - $213).

Collection of Rare Books, Records and Papers: The University Library maintains a collection of rare books and runs of bound of old magazines. The collection is increased either by purchases or donations, which are minimal. The University does not dispose of items in this collection. The University of Regina Archives collects the official records of the U of R, and private papers in various disciplines. The University Archives currently does not purchase or sell any items. All records and papers are transferred to or donated. Collection of Geographical Maps: The U of R's map library is a reference library containing maps, air photos, atlases, globes and documents on cartography and land use. Most additions come in the form of donations from the government and private individuals. It is also depository for the National Topographic Survey, who sends new and revised maps to the library monthly. The map library does not sell any items in its collection. Music Library Collection: The U of R faculty of Fine Arts maintains a collection of printed music for various ensembles and solo instruments. The music library does not sell any items in its collection, but may purchase very small amounts of new works to add to collections.

The University's Endowment Funds are to be kept permanently and are to earn investment income that can be paid out as scholarships, or as originally directed by the donors in the terms of reference, which may include bringing in guest speakers for classes.

This amount is composed of rental expenses ($14,453), loss on sale of assets ($90,389), change in pension accrual S176,328 and cost of goods sold ($3,437,181) which are netted against revenue for Form 990 IRS Return, but are included in expenses in the audited Financial Statements.
Same as reconciling items as for Revenue with inclusion of unrealized gain on interest rate swaps which is not included in the revenue and now netted against expenses for Form 990 IRS returns.

The University of Regina is a partially public funded Canadian University, There is no obligation in Canada requiring such policies or statements with respect to students. However, our Strategic Plan does indicate that "We are a learning community, we value interaction between faculty members and students as the fundamental activity of the academy. We recognize and support the diversity of our students needs, and are inclusive of our Aboriginal, new Canadian, international students, employees, and partners."
The U of R is a partially public funded Canadian University. It only keeps track of faculty members, staff or students who self-declared as a minority or as being Aboriginal or Metis.
The University of Regina is a partially public funded Canadian University. We receive an Operating Grant and a Capital Grant from the Saskatchewan Ministry of Advanced Education.
The University of Regina is a partially public funded University and is not subject to the noted legislation. We are required to follow Canadian legislation with respect to racial non-discrimination.

AccountActivitiesOutsideUSGrp.RegionTxt: North America (including Canada and Mexico, but not the United States)
AccountActivitiesOutsideUSGrp.SpecificServicesProvidedTxt: We are a Canadian University, so all of our services are provided in Canada and are fully described elsewhere in this return (Teaching, Research, Maintaining Facilities, Provision of Scholarships, etc). Please note: The University had a total number of employees equal to 4354. However, we did not put this amount in Form 990, part V, line 2(a) because we do not file US form W-3 for those employees (we file Canadian Form T4). Because we did not put a number in that box, there is also no number of employees showing in Form 990 part 1, Line 5.

GrantsToOrgOutsideUSGrp.RegionTxt: North America (including Canada and Mexico, but not the United States)
GrantsToOrgOutsideUSGrp.PurposeOfGrantTxt: Since we are a Canadian Organization, all of our grants are paid in Canada, which is outside the United States. Our grants are to support Students Organizations, Federated Colleges, and other Universities performing research (sub-grants)

ForeignIndividualsGrantsGrp.TypeOfAssistanceTxt: We are a Canadian Organization, all of our grants and the assistance to individuals are paid in Canada, which is outside of the United States. The amounts include general scholarships and awards, trust scholarships and bursaries.
ForeignIndividualsGrantsGrp.RegionTxt: North America (including Canada and Mexico, but not the United States)
ForeignIndividualsGrantsGrp.MannerOfCashDisbursementTxt: Cheque, EFT, or application to student accounts

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: We are a Canadian University, therefore we make grant payments to Canadian Organizations (which are outside of the US). Our grant to student organizations are monitored by the sponsoring faculty. Grants to federated colleges are monitored by accountants in Financial Services, and research sub-grants to other Canadian Universities are monitored by the Research Principal Investigator and the Research Accountants in Financial Services.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: University employees above the clerical level have accountable professional expense accounts. Each claim is reviewed to ensure it meets policies and is then signed by claimant's supervisor. The University President uses a University-owned house (and takes a taxable benefit into her income), and has a cleaning services for the house to be used after University events in the house.
The University of Regina uses CIBC Wood Gundy to process and sell any donations received in the form of shares. This is very rare.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 7a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Our Faculty Members (employees of the University) are allowed to elect one member to the Board of Governors.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: This Form 990 is completed by employees in Financial Services and is reviewed by the Director, Financial Reporting before filing.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: In May of each year or when Director/Trustee is brought on, the University's Secretary requires each Director/Trustee to complete and sign an updated conflict of interest form. Officers, such as out-of-scope employees, are also required to update their conflict of interest forms annually, or if any change occurs.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The President's salary is approved annually by the Board of Governors after a performance review (360 degree review), and after a review of market salaries. A written contract is prepared and signed by the President and the Board. The compensation structure and salaries of all out-of-scope key employees and officers is reviewed with the help of an external organization. The current compensation policy and structure were implemented in 2009.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Our governing document is "The University of Regina Act". This Act is made public on the Saskatchewan Queen's printer website. Our conflict of interest policy is contained in the University's on-line policy repository which is available to the public. The audited financial statements are available to the public through the University's Financial Services website.
Employee Future Benefit Re-measured as per CPA Canada Accounting Standards
